places.description: A dark and dense forest where Hansel and Gretel are abandoned.
A house made of candy and sweets, owned by the Witch.

facts.fact: Hansel is known for his cleverness and resourcefulness.
Gretel is known for her bravery and quick thinking.
The Witch is known for her cunning and malevolence.
The forest is dark and dense, making it easy to get lost.
The forest is home to many wild animals.
The Witch's house is made of candy and sweets.
The house has walls of gingerbread and cake.
The windows are made of clear sugar.
The roof is covered with various confections and sweets.
The Witch uses the house to lure children.
The house is enchanted to appear more inviting.
The Witch's house is located deep in the forest.
The house contains a large wood-burning oven used for cooking.
The oven is large enough for a person to crawl inside.
The house has a cage where the Witch imprisons children.
The interior of the house contrasts with its sweet exterior, being dark and sinister.
The house contains the Witch's treasure hoard of pearls and precious stones.
The Witch's house is ultimately destroyed by fire.

events.event: A great famine strikes the land, causing widespread hunger and desperation.
Hansel and Gretel's stepmother convinces their father to abandon the children in the forest due to lack of food.
Hansel overhears his parents' plan and fills his pockets with white pebbles.
The parents lead Hansel and Gretel deep into the forest under the pretense of gathering wood.
Hansel secretly drops white pebbles along the path as they walk deeper into the forest.
The parents abandon Hansel and Gretel in the forest, leaving them alone and lost.
Hansel and Gretel follow the trail of white pebbles back home in the moonlight.
The stepmother convinces the father to abandon the children again, this time ensuring they cannot return.
Hansel attempts to collect pebbles again but finds the door locked by his stepmother.
Hansel uses breadcrumbs from his breakfast instead of pebbles on the second abandonment attempt.
The parents lead Hansel and Gretel even deeper into the forest than before.
Birds eat all the breadcrumbs that Hansel dropped, leaving no trail to follow home.
Hansel and Gretel wander lost in the forest for three days, growing hungry and desperate.
A beautiful white bird leads Hansel and Gretel deeper into the forest with its enchanting song.
Hansel and Gretel discover a house made entirely of gingerbread, cake, and candy.
The hungry children begin eating pieces of the candy house to satisfy their hunger.
A voice from inside the house calls out, asking who is nibbling at the house.
The Witch emerges from the house, initially appearing kind and welcoming to the children.
The Witch invites Hansel and Gretel inside, offering them a feast of milk, pancakes, sugar, apples, and nuts.
The Witch provides soft beds for the children, making them feel safe and cared for.
The Witch reveals her true evil nature, planning to fatten and eat the children.
The Witch locks Hansel in a cage and forces Gretel to work as her servant.
The Witch feeds Hansel rich foods daily to fatten him up for cooking.
Hansel cleverly tricks the near-blind Witch by offering her a thin bone instead of his finger when she checks his weight.
The impatient Witch decides to cook Hansel regardless of his size and orders Gretel to prepare the oven.
The Witch asks Gretel to check if the oven is hot enough by crawling inside.
Gretel pretends not to understand how to get into the oven, asking the Witch to demonstrate.
Gretel pushes the Witch into the hot oven when she leans in to show how to crawl inside.
The Witch burns to death in her own oven, screaming horribly as she dies.
Gretel frees Hansel from his cage, and they celebrate their victory over the evil Witch.
Hansel and Gretel discover the Witch's treasure hoard of pearls and precious stones.
The children fill their pockets with the Witch's treasure before leaving the candy house.
Hansel and Gretel set out to find their way home through the unfamiliar forest.
A large body of water blocks their path, with no bridge or boat to cross.
A white duck helps ferry Hansel and Gretel across the water one at a time.
The children recognize familiar landmarks and realize they are near their home.
Hansel and Gretel arrive home to find their father alone, as their stepmother has died.
The father welcomes his children back with tears of joy and regret for abandoning them.
Hansel and Gretel share the Witch's treasure with their father, ending their family's poverty.
The family lives happily together, with no more worries about hunger or want.
